{{semiprotected|small=yes}} {{other uses}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2014}} {{refimprove|date=October 2012}} {{Infobox Military Cemetery |country= [[Taguig]], [[Metro Manila]], [[Philippines]] |name=Heroes' Cemetery
''Libingan ng mga Bayani'' |body= |image=[[File:Libingan ng Mga Bayani.jpg|300px]] |caption=Heroes' Cemetery |use_dates= |established=May 1947 (as Republic Memorial Cemetery) |designer= |location=Bayani Road, [[Taguig]], [[Philippines]] |coordinates={{coord|14.520|121.044}} |total= |unknowns= |by_country= |source= }} '''Heroes' Cemetery''', officially known as '''''{{lang|tl|Libingan ng mga Bayani}} (LNMB)''''', is a [[national cemetery]] within [[Fort Bonifacio]] (formerly Fort William McKinley) in Western Bicutan, [[Taguig]], [[Metro Manila]], [[Philippines]]. First established in May 1947 as a fitting resting place for Filipino military personnel from privates to generals who served during [[World War II]], it eventually became designated as the official place of burial for deceased [[President of the Philippines|Philippine Presidents]], national heroes, patriots, [[National Artist of the Philippines|National Artists]] and [[National Scientist of the Philippines|National Scientists]]. Among those buried in the cemetery are Filipino soldiers who died during the [[Philippines Campaign (1941–42)|Philippine Campaign]] and the [[Philippines campaign (1944–45)|Allied Liberation of the Philippines]] in World War II from 1941 to 1945. Among the Filipino leaders and dignitaries buried there are [[President of the Philippines|Presidents]] [[Elpidio Quirino]], [[Carlos P. Garcia]] and [[Diosdado Macapagal]]; former [[Vice-president of the Philippines|Vice-president]] [[Salvador H. Laurel]]; generals [[Artemio Ricarte]] and [[Carlos P. Romulo]]; [[Armed Forces of the Philippines|Armed Forces of the Philippines (AFP)]] [[Chief of Staff]] [[Angelo Reyes]]; and former Senate President and proclaimed Vice President [[Arturo Tolentino]] and [[Blas Ople]]. Former president and exile [[Ferdinand Edralin Marcos]] is the most recent president to be buried there, after the [[Supreme Court of the Philippines]] dismissed petitions against his burial on 8 November 2016.{{cite news|url=http://cnnphilippines.com/news/2016/11/08/Marcos-hero-burial-Libingan-ng-mga-Bayani-Supreme-Court.html|title= Supreme Court allows burial of Marcos at Heroes' Cemetery|work=[[CNN Philippines]]|date=November 8, 2016}} {{cite news|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/asia/1138589/hail-to-the-thief|title= Philippine dictator Marcos given hero's burial|work=[[Bangkok Post]]|date=November 18, 2016}} He was buried in a private ceremony, with [[military honors]], on November 18, 2016,{{cite news|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2016/11/18/1645056/armed-forces-instruction-was-keep-marcos-burial-secret|title=Armed Forces: Instruction was to keep Marcos burial a secret|work=[[The Philippine Star]]|date=November 18, 2016}} amid much controversy resulting in nationwide protests,{{Cite web|url=http://cnnphilippines.com/news/2016/11/19/Protesters-Marcos-burial.html|title=Protesters take to streets to denounce Marcos 'Libingan' burial|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}} and resulting a big traffic in Metro Manila {{Cite news|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2016/11/18/1645046/live-updates-burial-marcos-heroes-cemetery|title=LIVE updates: Protests after Ferdinand Marcos' burial|newspaper=philstar.com|access-date=2016-11-19}} ==History== [[File:Libingan Ng Mga Bayani.jpg|thumb|left|250px|The Libingan ng mga Bayani at ng mga Dating Pangulo or Heroes' Cemetery]] The cemetery was first established in May 1947 as the Republic Memorial Cemetery. It was first established as a tribute and final resting place for the 33,520 Filipino soldiers who died during the Philippine Campaign (1941–42) and the Allied Liberation of the Philippines (1944-45) in World War II.{{cite web|last=La Putt|first=Juny|title=Libingan ng mga Bayani (Cemetery of the Heroes)||url=http://corregidorisland.com/bayani/libingan.html|publisher=CorregidorIsland.com|accessdate=16 August 2016}}{{cite web|title=Libingan ng mga Bayani |work=Taguig Landmarks|url=http://www.taguig.gov.ph/tourism/taguig-landmarks/|publisher=City Government of Taguig|accessdate=16 August 2016}} It was established as the Filipino counterpart to the [[Manila American Cemetery and Memorial]], which houses the remains of [[United States]] personnel who died during the same war.{{cite book|last=Rodell|first=Paul A.|title=Culture and customs of the Philippines|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|year=2002|page=93|isbn=0-313-30415-7|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=y1CVR74_KHQC&pg=PA93&dq=libingan+ng+mga+bayani&lr=|accessdate=16 June 2009}} On 16 June 1948, Philippine President Elpidio Quirino signed into law the Republic Act 289, also known as ''An Act Providing for the Construction of a National Pantheon for Presidents of the Philippines, National Heroes, and Patriots of the Country''.{{cite web |url=http://www.chanrobles.com/republicacts/republicactno289.html |title=Republic Act No. 289-An Act Providing for the Construction of a National Pantheon for Presidents of the Philippines, National Heroes, and Patriots of the Country |publisher=Chan Robles Virtual Law Library|accessdate=1 July 2011}} Section 1 of the Act cites the purpose of creating such pantheon: {{quotation|"''To perpetuate the memory of all the Presidents of the Philippines, national heroes and patriots for the inspiration and emulation of this generation and of generations still unborn...''"}} While such National Pantheon was never established during Quirino's lifetime,{{cite web|title=Why not Libingan ng mga Pangulo instead? |url=http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/nation/06/30/11/why-not-libingan-ng-mga-pangulo-instead|publisher=ABS-CBN News|accessdate=16 August 2016}} several decrees and laws passed under succeeding administrations led to the eventual use of the Republic Memorial Cemetery as a national pantheon described in Republic Act 289. On 27 October 1954, President [[Ramon Magsaysay]] renamed the Republic Memorial Cemetery as the Libingan ng mga Bayani. On 28 May 1967, President [[Ferdinand Marcos]] issued Presidential Proclamation No. 208 ordering the reservation of 142 hectares of land within Fort Bonifacio in consideration for the Libingan to serve not only as a cemetery for military personnel but also as a national shrine for fallen heroes. He ordered it placed under the administration of the Military Shrines Services of the [[Philippine Veterans Affairs Office]], an agency under the [[Department of National Defense (Philippines)|Department of National Defense]].{{cite web|title=Libingan ng mga Bayani |work=Our Heritage and the Departed: A Cemeteries Tour |url=http://malacanang.gov.ph/undas-2012-a-cemeteries-tour/|publisher=Presidential Museum and Library|accessdate=16 August 2016}} On 9 April 1986, Armed Forces of the Philippines Chief of Staff [[Fidel Ramos]] and President [[Corazon Aquino]] issued Armed Forces Regulations G 161-373, also known as "''The allocation of Cemetery Plots at the LNMB''". This military-issued regulation established the internment policy that would become the basis for the burial of personalities at the Libingan ng mga Bayani.{{cite web|url=http://malacanang.gov.ph/77188-quick-facts-about-the-presidency/ |title=Quick facts about the Presidency |publisher=Presidential Museum and Library |accessdate=16 August 2016}}{{cite web|last=D. Pascual Jr.|first=Federico|title=Trudging back to old haunts and bad habits|url=http://www.philstar.com:8080/opinion/678581/trudging-back-old-haunts-and-bad-habits|publisher=''[[The Philippine Star]]''|accessdate=7 August 2013|date=23 April 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.mb.com.ph/afp-rules-for-libingan-ng-mga-bayani/#kEt5ODpDcAeCyPkd.99|title=AFP explains rules for ‘Libingan ng mga Bayani’|first=Aben|last=Elena|publisher=''[[The Manila Bulletin]]'' |date=27 May 2016 |accessdate=16 August 2016}} Moreover, by virtue of Executive Order No. 131 issued by former President Fidel Ramos on 26 October 1993, National Artists and National Scientists of the Philippines were also made eligible for interment at the cemetery.{{cite web |title=Executive Order No. 131 - Facilitating the State Funeral of Deceased National Artists and National Scientists |date=26 October 1993 |publisher=The Official Gazette of the Republic of the Philippines |accessdate=16 August 2016}} In 2007, due to overcrowding at the Fort Bonifacio site, the cemetery's administration started exploring sites for Libingan ng mga Bayani annexes in [[Luzon]], [[Visayas]] and [[Mindanao]]. Only one has been completed so far, the [[Philippine peso|₱]]24-million, five-hectare extension at Camp Hernandez in [[Dingle, Iloilo|Dingle]], [[Iloilo province|Iloilo]].{{cite web|last=Dizon |first=Nikko |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2479&dat=20071104&id=i1Q1AAAAIBAJ&sjid=YiUMAAAAIBAJ&pg=2231,14937628&hl=en |title=Burial space for soldiers running out |date=4 November 2007 |publisher=''[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]'' |accessdate=16 August 2016}} ==Administration== The cemetery is administered and maintained by the Grave Service Unit (GSU), a unit of the Philippine Army Support Command of the AFP. Its mission is to provide burial and niche services to deceased military personnel and other personalities interred at the cemetery. Aside from maintaining the cemetery and the military grave site at [[Manila North Cemetery]], the unit is also capable of providing mortuary and memorial services to authorized personnel. ==Interment policy== According to Armed Forces of the Philippines (AFP) Regulation G 161-373, the following persons are entitled to interment at Heroes' Cemetery: * [[Philippine Medal of Valor|Medal of Valor]] awardees * Presidents or Commanders-in-Chief, AFP * The [[Secretary of National Defense (Philippines)|secretaries of National Defense]] * AFP Chiefs of Staff * General/Flag Officers * Active and retired military personnel of the AFP * Former AFP members who laterally entered/joined the [[Philippine National Police]] (PNP) and the [[Philippine Coast Guard]] (PCG) * Veterans of the [[Philippine Revolution]] of 1896, the [[First World War|First]] and [[Second World War]]s, as well as recognized guerrillas * Government dignitaries, statesmen, national artists and other deceased persons whose interment has been approved by the commander-in-chief, Congress or the Secretary of National Defense, and * Former Presidents, Secretaries of National Defense, widows of former Presidents, Secretaries of National Defense and Chiefs of Staff * National Artists and National Scientists of the Philippines However, the same regulation also prohibits “personnel who were dishonorably separated/ reverted/ discharged from the service and personnel who were convicted by final judgment of an offense involving moral turpitude” from interment at the Heroes' Cemetery. ==Features== [[File:Libingan ng mga Bayani.jpg|thumb|250px|left|Tombstones of fallen Filipino soldiers at the Heroes' Cemetery]] The first structure that visitors will see upon entering the grounds of the cemetery complex is the Heroes Memorial Gate, a large concrete tripod with a stairway leading to an upper view deck with a metal sculpture at the center. Erected on opposite sides of the main entrance road near the Heroes Memorial Gate are two 12-foot high black stone walls which bear the words that [[Douglas MacArthur|General Douglas MacArthur]] uttered during a journey to the Philippines in 1961: "I do not know the dignity of his birth, but I do know the glory of his death." The main structure, located at the center of the cemetery, is the [[Tomb of the Unknown Soldier]], where wreath laying ceremonies are held when Philippine government officials and foreign dignitaries visit the cemetery. Inscripted on the tomb are the words: "Here lies a Filipino soldier whose name is known only to God." Behind the tomb are three marble pillars representing the three main island groups in the Philippines: Luzon, Visayas, and Mindanao. There are several pylons as well commemorating the gallantry of Filipino soldiers who died in various wars in world history. These include the Korean Memorial Pylon, which honors 112 Filipino officers and men who were members of the [[Philippine Expeditionary Forces to Korea|Philippine Expeditionary Forces to Korea (PEFTOK)]] who perished during the [[Korean War]]; the Vietnam Veterans Memorial Pylon, which was dedicated to the members of the Philippine contingent and Philippine civic action groups (PHILCON-V and PHILCAG-V) that were sent to [[Vietnam]] during the [[Vietnam War]] from 1964 to 1971; and the Philippine World War II Guerrillas Pylon, which was erected by the Veterans Federation of the Philippines as a testimony to the indomitable spirit and bravery of the Filipino guerrillas of World War II. == Notable burials == * [[Elpidio Quirino]], 6th [[President of the Philippines|President]]{{cite news|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/769165/after-60-years-president-quirino-gets-burial-he-deserves|title=After 60 years, President Quirino gets burial he deserves|first=Jaymee T. Gamil, Nikko|last=Dizon|work=Philippine Daily Inquirer|accessdate=19 November 2016}} * [[Carlos P. Garcia]], 8th President * [[Diosdado Macapagal]], 9th President * [[Ferdinand Marcos]], 10th President * [[Arturo Tolentino]], former [[Secretary of Foreign Affairs (Philippines)|Secretary of Foreign Affairs]] and [[Senate President of the Philippines|Senator]] * [[Salvador H. Laurel]], 10th Vice President * [[Artemio Ricarte]], [[Philippine Revolutionary Army]] Chief of Staff * [[Carlos P. Romulo]], [[Secretary of Foreign Affairs (Philippines)|Secretary of Foreign Affairs]] and [[Senator of the Philippines|Senator]] * [[Angelo Reyes]], [[Armed Forces of the Philippines]] Chief of Staff * [[Blas Ople]], [[Secretary of Foreign Affairs (Philippines)|Secretary of Foreign Affairs]] and [[Senator of the Philippines|Senator]] *[[Fe Del Mundo]], a Philippine pediatrician whose studies led to the improvement of the [[Incubator (neonatal)|neonatal incubator]] ==See also== * [[Burial of Ferdinand Marcos]] * [[Capas National Shrine]] * [[Mount Samat National Shrine]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{commons category inline}} * {{cite web|url=http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=cr&GSln=Laurel&CRid=2183037&pt=Libingan%20ng%20mga%20Bayani%20(Cemetery%20of%20the%20Heroes)&|title=Libingan ng mga Bayani (Cemetery of the Heroes)|publisher=Find A Grave|accessdate=16 June 2009}} (coordinates) {{Philippine Military Shrines}} {{Philippine Registry of Cultural Property}} {{Bonifacio Global City}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Libingan Ng Mga Bayani}} [[Category:Military cemeteries]] [[Category:Cemeteries in Metro Manila]] [[Category:Landmarks in the Philippines]] [[Category:National Shrines of the Philippines]] [[Category:Cultural Properties of the Philippines in Metro Manila]]
